prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not changing the movie that I chose for my birthday.
so this happened a while ago and I'm curious if I was the asshole.

It was just before my 20th birthday and I decided I wanted to see a movie as my birthday party/gift to myself, I discovered that How to Train Your Dragon 3 was out so I thought id go see it. 

I posted on the group chat the date and time of the movie and asked if anybody wanted to join me for a birthday movie. I said its completely optional if you want to join me. 

most of the group agreed and I was happy. 
That was until one of them said why don't we pick a different movie, I replied saying that it was my birthday and it's the movie I picked, we could see another movie on another day if you want, but I really want to see How to Train Your Dragon. 

After realising they wouldn't change my mind they told me they weren't coming and stopped talking in the group chat. 

I'm now unsure if I should have changed the movie or not.

AITA?

and just incase anyone asks, I like how to train your dragon because it's a good movie. 
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The user is asking if the person who wrote the story is the asshole for not changing the movie choice. The situation is that they wanted to see How to Train Your Dragon 3 for their birthday and invited friends. One person suggested changing the movie, the author refused, and then that person didn't come and stopped talking.

First, the author made it clear it was optional for others to join. They didn't force anyone to come. When someone suggested a different movie, the author stood by their choice, which is their right since it's their birthday. The person who suggested changing the movie didn't get their way and left. 

The key points are: the author didn't make attendance mandatory, communicated the movie choice in advance, and offered to watch another movie another time. The other person's reaction seems a bit extreme since the author was firm but polite. It's possible that the other person had different preferences or felt snubbed, but the author wasn't wrong in sticking to their choice for their own celebration. 

I think the author isn't in the wrong. They had the right to choose their movie for their birthday party. The responsibility for not attending lies with the other person, not the author. So the answer is B.
